title: Ticket #6540: Preen should clean up core dump files
description:
By default, preen does not clean up core dump files in the $(LOG) folder. This could lead to the file system filling up, if enough processes crash and nothing cleans out the core files.

Let's make preen clean these up. We need to figure a policy, since core dumps can also be useful for debugging and should not be erased indiscriminately. I propose that files older than 30 days get removed. Thoughts?
remarks:
2018-Apr-23 15:14:48 by jfrey:
Code Review

  • Your commits have the wrong ticket number (#6520 instead of #6540).

  • "Process" isn't the best term. Something like PROGRAM would be more accurate.

  • Should this code (particularly get_corefile_process()) be marked unix-only?

  • Use our my_popen() function instead of popen(). Our version doesn't invoke the shell, so no one can play games with cleverly-crafted filenames.

  • In get_corefile_process(), a unique_ptr would be better than a shared_ptr.

  • In get_corefile_process(), what if the output of 'file' is malformed? For example, if the token after "execfn:" isn't something like '/foo/bar', then string::substr() can throw an exception.

  • In check_log_dir(), there are several situations in which a file isn't marked as good or bad. Is that the best action in these cases?
    • Two core files have the same timestamp.
    • Stat'ing the file fails.
    • get_corefile_process() fails to return an executable name.

  • 10Mb seems like an awfully low default for max core file size. We'd delete all core files for a moderately busy schedd, collector, or negotiator.

2018-Apr-24 14:10:53 by jfrey:
Code Review, cont.

  • You can get core files on windows, though they're little more than a stack trace. Running 'file' won't work there.

  • Consider using our run_command() function. It uses our my_popen() to run a command, then returns all of the output in a buffer. It also has a timeout.

2018-Apr-27 15:45:23 by coatsworth:
I've fixed most of the things you mentioned, you can see them in the github comparison:

https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/compare/V8_6-branch...V8_6-gt6520-core-cleanup

A few comments:

* First, my main design philosophy here is we don't want to accidentally delete important files. If we're unsure about a file for whatever reason, we ignore it. If we can't stat a core file, or we can't identify who created it, ignore it. The the 'file' command returns weird output, ignore it. I don't want to flag the file as good because we don't actually know if it's good. But good files and ignored files get treated the same: they don't get erased.

* Sorry about the wrong ticket number, I named my branch wrong and then the error spilled over into my commit messages :( Is this a big deal? Should I nuke the branch and make a new one with new commits?

* We're not going to check core files on Windows. I've #ifdef-ed this all out.

* In get_corefile_process(), the shared_ptr constructor is much easier to construct with a pointer and deleter. I couldn't get unique_ptr to work. Is it okay if I leave as is?

* I decided not to use run_command because it's not used anywhere in the condor codebase, I figured there must be a reason for that.

* Default for max core file size is now 50 Mb, does that sound reasonable? If not let me know what's a good number.

2018-May-03 11:49:05 by jfrey:
Code Review

The current code looks ok.

In reply to your comments:

  • "When in doubt, leave it alone" sounds like the right approach.

  • No need to change anything due to the wrong ticket number. Making the branch name and commits visible in this ticket is sufficient.

  • shared_ptr is fine, if unique_ptr is being a butt. I haven't used a custom deleter with either, but the docs made it look like they would work the same.

  • TJ recommended run_command(), which he added not too long ago. Given that no other code is using it, avoiding it seems appropriate.

  • The default max core file size is something we should probably poll the rest of the FW team about.
